bcrypt: Adaptive, salted, one-way password hashing function

AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Uses a key for both encryption and decryption; the same key must be kept secret
bcrypt: Does not use a key for “decryption”; instead, hashes are compared for password validation

AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Operates on 128-bit blocks using keys of 128, 192, or 256 bits
bcrypt: Based on the Blowfish cipher; includes salt and cost factor

AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Ciphertext—can be decrypted back to original data with the correct key
bcrypt: Hash—cannot be reversed; original password cannot be obtained from output

AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Uses IV (Initialization Vector) for block cipher modes for randomness, not traditional salt
bcrypt: Uses a unique random salt for each password to ensure unique hashes even for identical passwords

AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Reversible—data can be decrypted if you have the key
bcrypt: Irreversible—hash is one-way; password cannot be recovered from hash

AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Encrypting files, communications, and databases; protecting data at rest or in transit
bcrypt: Storing and validating user passwords securely (authentication)

AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Security is based on key secrecy and proper IV management
bcrypt: Adjustable computational cost (“work factor”) to slow down brute-force attacks, making hashing intentionally slow

AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Key management, IV reuse/poor entropy, implementation flaws
bcrypt: Outdated cost = vulnerable to faster CPUs or GPUs, but still generally safe if configured right

AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Very fast, especially with hardware acceleration
bcrypt: Intentionally slow, to resist brute-force attacks
